name: hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/4453/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg hard coal (useable output) in the specific region with an energy content of 17.3 MJ/kg pit coal. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for operation. Additionally, 100 years of life time are taken into account due to the assumption that land after operation is destroyed and not useable for a long time. Thus, land recultivation is not considered in the dataset. After 120 years, revegetation of land is expected. This dataset is based on various literature studies on material flows and energy use. Data regarding land use for operational areas for infrastructure, extraction areas and dump areas have been estimated. Hard coal in Latin America is mined in open pit mines, therefore no underground mines are taken into account in this dataset. Land use for affected water supply areas only represent rough estimations. Data regarding land use are not valid for specific regions, for this, higher uncertainties are considered. In this dataset infrastructure requirements are applied to total production over the life time. For this, the total production has to be estimated. A total production over life time of 3*10^10 kg is assumed. This figure represents an average value and is not representative for single mines or specific conditions.

Mining process starting from hard coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal at the coal mine. This dataset includes land use during operation, emissions to water and air, water extraction during pumping, energy requirements for operation, explosives, as well as the deposition of spoil. This dataset doesn’t include noise emissions; however they are expected to be wide-ranging. The amount of geothermal energy directly or indirectly emitted to air by extraction of hot pit water or increased evaporation is not considered due to the lack of data.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Compared to lignite, hard coal seams are much thinner but in most cases up to 20 seams are located one above the other. In general seam thickness ranges from 2 to 10 meters; the seams are located up to a depth of 100 meters. In hard coal opencast mines often lorries and bucket excavators are used. Due to the fact that hard coal is embedded in hard rock formations and hard coal itself is rather hard, the rock formations have to be blasted, thus significant amounts of explosives are required.; ;;In this dataset it is assumed that the total amount of coal is treated, particularly for export coal high calorific values and low sulfuric contents are required. Data regarding mine waste is based on Hinrichs. ;;In this dataset a processing efficiency factor of 95 % (opencast mining) and 92 % (underground mining) is assumed. Mine waste is partly recycled or disposed. Energetic use of flotation tailings in fluidized bed combustion is not included in the dataset due to insufficient information and insignificant amounts; assuming complete utilization, only 20 % of combustible matter can be recycled.;;;References:;Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Deutschland.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. In opencast mines coal output amounts to 90-95 %. Due to the fact that only extracted coal is considered as resource, no mean value has to be estimated. The heat value of pit hard coal ranges from 15 to 30 MJ/kg. 

In this dataset 100 % of coal is mined in opencast mines. 

At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated. The calculated values are in accordance with data given in Hinrichs. In this mining region a gross calorific value of 19.1 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated, based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production.This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange “coal, hard, unspecified in ground”. 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,245 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are extracted. 


Further references:

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hischier R., Hellweg S., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2004c) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.
EcoSpold01Location=RLA

Estimation. According to Astakhov and DOE mine water amounts to 0.5 m3/t with an average value of 0.2 m3/t for opencast mines. Regarding opencast mines lower water amounts are expected. Due to lower depths and smaller seams also low salt contens are expected. Based on these facts it is assumed that 200 l/t water are pumped with a salt content of 0.5 g/l (i.e. 0.1 kg/t useable output). Respective emissions are calculated based on the share of coal mining in opencast and underground mines. 

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

Estimation. In this dataset it is assumed that released methane is used for the production of energy. Thus, released methane is accounted for as natural gas resource in this module.

flow.name: Gas, mine, off-gas, process, coal mining

exchanges.description:
This value represents fugitive CH4 emissions from mining, processing, storage and transportation of coal:
These emissions are calculated based on the average emission factors for mine operation and post-mining activities of underground and surface coal mines suggested by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories (Chapter 4.1 Fugitive emissions from mining, processing, storage and transportation of coal, p. 4.11 ff., accessible at <https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_4_Ch4_Fugitive_Emissions.pdf>, July 2018).
Average CH4 emission factors according to IPCC 2006 are:
underground coal production = 18m3/tonne = 12.06 kg/tonne
post-mining emissions, underground mines = 2.5m3/tonne = 1.675 kg/tonne
surface coal production = 1.2m3/tonne = 0.804 kg/tonne
post mining emissions, surface mines = 0.1m3/tonne =0.067 kg/tonne
Ch4 density at 20 degrees Celsius and 1 bar is 0.67kg/m3.
The applied share of coal from underground and surface mines in Colombia (representing coal mining in RLA) is 0 % and 100 %, respectively (Dones et al., 2007).
Under this approach the calculated CH4 emissions in Latin America amount to 0.000871 kg CH4/kg coal. The uncertainty of this value is high. Nonetheless, this approach was considered more reliable by ecoinvent industry experts than the previously estimated value by Dones et al. (2007).
Reference(s):
Dones, R., Bauer, C., Röder, A. (2007) Kohle. In: Dones, R. (Ed.) et al., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen: Grundlagen für den ökologischen Vergleich von Energiesystemen und den Einbezug von Energiesystemen in Ökobilanzen für die Schweiz. Final report ecoinvent No. 6-VI, Paul Scherrer Institut Villigen, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
IPCC, 2006, IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories, Chapter 4.1 Fugitive emissions from mining, processing, storage and transportation of coal, p. 4.11 ff., accessible at <https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/public/2006gl/pdf/2_Volume2/V2_4_Ch4_Fugitive_Emissions.pdf>, July 2018

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Due to the lack of data, this estimation represents an average of all other mining regions. Estimations done for other mining regions, see below:

Opencast mine: Based on the share of opencast mines and average seam thickness primary land use can be estimated. Regarding hard coal mining primary land use amounts to 0.019 m2 /t pit coal. No classification of former utilization classes was possible. According to the quality guidelines life time is assumed to be 20 years.

In OECD 1985 it is said that mainly outside Europe land is not recultivated due to high costs. However, this has to be considered in the dataset. After operation, land is destroyed and not useable for a long time. For this, additionally 100 years of life time are assumed, because after 120 years revegetation is expected. Due to the lack of data, this figure only represents a rough estimation.
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated. The calculated values are in accordance with data given in Hinrichs. In this mining region a gross calorific value of 19.1 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated, based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production.This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange "coal, hard, unspecified in ground". 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,245 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are extracted.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Estimation. The primary literature source is Hinrichs, for comparative purposes also previous editions of the Life Cycle Inventories are used. 

A major part of energy is used for diesel due to the fact that mainly lorries are used for transports within the mine. There are big differences between energy consumption of the different hard coal mines, thus it is difficult to generalize. Based on various literature sources, country-specific shares of production and plausibility considerations an average value is estimated. Regarding opencast mines it is assumed that only electricity and diesel is required.In this dataset it is assumed that total diesel consumption is used in construction machines, because lorries and construction machines show comparable emissions per kg diesel. 

Further references:

World Energy Conference (1989) Environmental Effects Arising from Electricity Supply and Utilisation and the Resulting Costs to the Utility. London.

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Germany.

Estimation. Regarding particulates, only those are considered which are not emitted during the combustion process and which are not deposited within the mining area. In AP 42 information about situational particle emission calculations and characteristical particle size distribution are given. 90 % of dust particles show sizes between 15 and 30 um, 10 % of dust particles are smaller than 15 um, 6 % of dust particles are smaller than 10 um and between 0.2 % und 1 % are smaller than 2.54 um. Regarding underground mining marginal emissions due to ventilation and slightly more emissions due to coal handling and the actual treatment step are estimated. Regarding opencast mining sharply increased emissions due to huge mining machines, lorries and open pits are estimated. Furthermore, emissions depend on climatic conditions (wind, precipitation, temperature) and the characteristics of coal (water content). In the literature figures regarding particle emissions range from 22 to 75 g/t. In this dataset particle emissions of 36 g/t are considered.

In various literature sources no information about other emissions emitted during underground mining are given respectively insignificant amounts are assumed, even though backfill processes show high specific emissions. 

In this dataset the following particle emissions factors are estimated: 

Particle emissions underground mining incl. treatment: 0.1 kg/t useable output

Particle emissions opencast mining incl. treatment: 0.4 kg/t useable output.

All emissions are assumed to be fly ash coarse particles (i.e. > 10 um).

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Rentz O. (1991) Coal Use and Air Pollution Issues. In: Proceedings Coal in the Environment. London.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Regarding radon emissions extensive measurements were taken to develop a measurement methodology and to review operating conditions. (Müller et al. 1992) 

Radon concentrations in air flow when leaving the shaft installations are most important to estimate specific radon emissions. Immission measurements at different measuring points (also badly aerated sites) show figures between 80 and 500 Bq/m3 (i.e. mean value of 200 Bq/m3). It was not possible to allocate specific air flow amounts per t extracted coal. According to about 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. (UNSCEAR 1988) No differentiation between opencast and underground mines has been made due to the lack of data. This figure is used in this dataset. 

Further references:

Müller W.-U., Streffer C., Schabronath J. (1992) Die Radonexposition im Steinkohlenbergbau des Ruhrgebietes. In: Reiners Ch., Streffer C., Messerschmidt O., Strahlenrisiko durch Radon. 32. Jahrestagung der Vereinigung Deutscher Strahlenschutzärzte e.V. in Essen 30. Mai - 1. Juni 1991, Stuttgart.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE
Estimation. The primary literature source is Hinrichs, for comparative purposes also previous editions of the Life Cycle Inventories are used.

 A major part of energy is used for electricity due to the fact that heavy mining and underground machinery is mainly powered by electricity. There are big differences between energy consumption of the different hard coal mines, thus it is difficult to generalize. Based on various literature sources, country-specific shares of production and plausibility considerations an average value is estimated. Regarding opencast mines it is assumed that only electricity and diesel is required.

Electricity is often derived from mine-mouth power plants, which are powered with low-grad coal (i.e. coal with higher ash content and lower heat value). High voltage electricity (UCTE-mix) is used. Emissions in this dataset are likely to be underestimated due to the following assumptions: 50 % of hard coal is mined outside the UCTE-region, electricity supply in these regions is primarily based on fossil energy sources and environmental standards are often below European standards. However, these assumptions are not considered in the dataset because all energy systems obtain electricity at European power plants. This would considerably increase loading of imported coal.  

Further references:

World Energy Conference (1989) Environmental Effects Arising from Electricity Supply and Utilisation and the Resulting Costs to the Utility. London.

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Dohmen A., Hagen G., Groten A. (1998) Der Steinkohlentagebau Rietspruit/ Republik Südafrika. In: Braunkohle 40, Heft 1/2, s.24-29.

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Germany.
